item.title: typescript vs flow
item.description:
Recently I’m evaluating both these type systems for javascript and this blog post is to summarize my findings so far.

What I like about flow:

  • Having sound type system is their design goal
  • You can use it with https://github.com/gcanti/babel-plugin-tcomb to get runtime assertions

What I don’t like about flow:

  • You can’t have nominal typing for IDs in easy way - This could save from some bugs
  • Flow doesn’t evaluate imported functions defined in other files by default - this is minor for me
  • Weird errors when you do mistake - I don’t do mistakes ;) so it’s not so big problem for me
  • I’ve read it’s hard to check where type coverage is missing to achieve 100% static coverage - this is big

What I like about TypeScript:

  • Better tooling
  • Ability to express nominal typing for numbers and string

What I don’t like about TypeScript:

  • Doesn’t even try to have sound type system.
  • Don’t have ability to turn on runtime assertion - but it supossedly works cross files better, so maybe it’s not necessary. There are libs which allow to check input based on types though, but you have to manually invoke it(usefull for IO).
  • More to come after I test it better…
